American Idol Season 21

American Idol Season 21 was the twenty-first season of the popular reality television singing competition series American Idol. The season premiered on February 19, 2023, on the Fox network and concluded on May 21, 2023, with a live finale broadcast from the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California.

#Auditions

The auditions for Season 21 were held in various cities across the United States, including Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, and Nashville. The audition process consisted of three rounds: the initial audition, the callback audition, and the Hollywood round. The initial auditions were held in each of the cities listed above, with the top contestants advancing to the callback auditions, which were held in Los Angeles.

The callback auditions were a more rigorous process, with contestants performing in front of a panel of judges, including Luke Bryan, Katy Perry, and Lionel Richie. The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were invited to the Hollywood round.

#Hollywood Week

Hollywood week was a grueling process that tested the contestants' vocal abilities, stage presence, and ability to perform under pressure. The contestants were divided into groups and performed in front of a live audience, with the judges providing feedback and guidance throughout the process.

The contestants performed a variety of songs, including solo performances and group numbers. The judges assessed their performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the next round, while those who struggled were eliminated.

#Showstopper Round

The showstopper round was a new addition to the competition this season. The contestants were given a short amount of time to prepare for a dramatic, high-energy performance. The performances were judged on their creativity, originality, and overall impact.

The contestants were given a range of options for their performances, including a selection of popular songs, as well as the opportunity to choose their own song. The judges were impressed by the contestants' performances, with many of them showcasing their unique talents and style.

#Top 26 (April 16 & 17)

The top 26 contestants were announced on April 16 and 17, with the contestants performing in front of a live audience and a panel of judges. The contestants performed a variety of songs, including solo performances and group numbers.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 20, while those who struggled were eliminated.

#Top 20 (April 23 & 24)

The top 20 contestants were announced on April 23 and 24, with the contestants performing in front of a live audience and a panel of judges. The contestants performed a variety of songs, including solo performances and group numbers.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 12, while those who struggled were eliminated.

#Finals

##Top 12 – Rock and Roll Hall of Fame (April 30)

The top 12 contestants performed at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, Ohio, on April 30. The contestants performed a variety of songs, including classic rock hits and original compositions.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 10, while those who struggled were eliminated.

##Top 10 – Judges' song contest (May 1)

The top 10 contestants participated in a song contest, with the judges providing them with a selection of songs to choose from. The contestants performed in front of a live audience and a panel of judges.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 8, while those who struggled were eliminated.

##Top 8 – Alanis Morissette & Ed Sheeran (May 7)

The top 8 contestants performed at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California, on May 7. The contestants performed a variety of songs, including Alanis Morissette and Ed Sheeran hits and original compositions.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 5, while those who struggled were eliminated.

##Top 5 – Disney (May 14)

The top 5 contestants performed at the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California, on May 14. The contestants performed a variety of Disney-themed songs, including classic hits and original compositions.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and those who impressed them the most were advanced to the top 3, while those who struggled were eliminated.

##Top 3 – Finale (May 21)

The top 3 contestants performed at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California, on May 21. The contestants performed a variety of songs, including original compositions and a final performance of their signature song.

The judges assessed the contestants' performances, and the winner was announced live on stage.

#Elimination Chart

Bigg Boss (Tamil TV series) season 7

Bigg Boss Tamil season 7 is the seventh season of the reality TV show Bigg Boss Tamil, which premiered on 12 July 2022 on Star Vijay. The season was hosted by comedian and actor Vijay Tejashwini. The season features 16 contestants competing for a cash prize of ₹50 lakhs (US$66,000) and the title of Bigg Boss Tamil season 7 winner.

Production

### Eye logo

The eye logo of Bigg Boss season 7 is a prominent feature of the show's branding. The logo features a stylized eye with a bold and vibrant design. The logo is often used as a symbol of the show's theme and is displayed prominently during the show's opening credits and throughout the season.

### House themes

The Bigg Boss season 7 house had two main themes: Luxury House and Small House.

#### Luxury house

The Luxury House was the main living area of the Bigg Boss season 7 contestants. It was a spacious and luxurious room with a large kitchen, a dining area, and a living room. The Luxury House was equipped with all modern amenities, including air conditioning, a gym, and a swimming pool.

#### Small house

The Small House was a smaller living area that was introduced in the second week of the season. It was a smaller version of the Luxury House and was equipped with basic amenities. The Small House was introduced as a twist in the show, and contestants had to compete for a place in the Luxury House.

Concept

The concept of Bigg Boss season 7 was to bring together 16 contestants from different walks of life and put them in a house with limited resources. The contestants had to compete with each other to win the title of Bigg Boss Tamil season 7 winner and the cash prize of ₹50 lakhs. The show was designed to test the contestants' physical and mental strength, their ability to work in teams, and their ability to adapt to new situations.

Teaser

The teaser of Bigg Boss season 7 was released on 29 June 2022. The teaser featured a glimpse of the show's host, Vijay Tejashwini, and the contestants in the house. The teaser also featured a glimpse of the Luxury House and the Small House.

Voting process

The voting process in Bigg Boss season 7 was similar to previous seasons. Viewers could vote for their favorite contestants through the Star Vijay app or through the show's website. The contestant with the highest number of votes would be saved from nomination, while the contestant with the lowest number of votes would be nominated for eviction.

Release

Bigg Boss season 7 premiered on 12 July 2022 on Star Vijay. The show was broadcast in a weeknight format, with new episodes airing every Monday to Friday at 9:30 PM IST.

Housemate status

The housemates in Bigg Boss season 7 were divided into two groups: original entrants and wildcard entrants.

### Original entrants

The original entrants in Bigg Boss season 7 were the 14 contestants who entered the house on day one. They were:

1. Abhinay Vaddi
2. Archana Chandhoke
3. Diana Khan
4. Dhanalakshmi
5. Dhanush
6. Hema Chaudhary
7. Kiran
8. Mohan Vaidya
9. Nishanth
10. Priyanka Deshpande
11. Raju Jeyamohan
12. Shariq Hasan
13. Suresh Chakravarthy
14. Varun

### Wildcard entrants

The wildcard entrants in Bigg Boss season 7 were the two contestants who entered the house as a surprise in the third week. They were:

1. Aari Arjunan
2. Thamarai Selvi

Twists

Bigg Boss season 7 had several twists, including:

#### Launch day captaincy

The launch day captaincy was a twist in which the contestants had to compete for the captaincy of the house. The contestant who won the captaincy challenge would be the captain of the house for the first week.

#### Star medal

The Star medal was a twist in which the contestants had to compete for a star-shaped medal. The contestant who won the Star medal would be given an advantage in the next week's nomination process.

#### Cursed Stone (Sabakkal)

The Cursed Stone was a twist in which the contestants had to compete for a stone that would bring them bad luck. The contestant who won the Cursed Stone would be given a disadvantage in the next week's nomination process.

Main House vs. Small House

The Main House vs. Small House twist was a major part of Bigg Boss season 7. In the second week, the contestants had to compete for a place in the Luxury House. The contestants who won the competition would be moved to the Luxury House, while the contestants who lost would be moved to the Small House.

#### Introduction of Small Boss house

The Small Boss house was introduced in the second week of the season. It was a smaller version of the Luxury House and was equipped with basic amenities.

#### Chinna Boss

Chinna Boss was a twist in which the contestants had to compete for a small boss title. The contestant who won the title would be given an advantage in the next week's nomination process.

#### Housemate allotment

The housemate allotment was a twist in which the contestants had to compete for a place in the Luxury House. The contestants who won the competition would be moved to the Luxury House, while the contestants who lost would be moved to the Small House.

Gold stars

The gold stars were a twist in Bigg Boss season 7. The contestant who won the gold stars would be given an advantage in the next week's nomination process.

Bigg Boss Jail

Bigg Boss Jail was a twist in Bigg Boss season 7. The contestant who went to jail would be given a disadvantage in the next week's nomination process.

Guest appearances

Several celebrities made guest appearances on Bigg Boss season 7, including:

* Vikram
* Kajal Aggarwal
* Samantha Ruth Prabhu
* Trisha Krishnan
* R. Madhavan
* Jayam Ravi

Weekly summary

The weekly summary of Bigg Boss season 7 was as follows:

Week 1: The first week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the introduction of the 14 original contestants. The contestants had to compete for the captaincy of the house, which was won by Priyanka Deshpande.

Week 2: The second week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the introduction of the Small House. The contestants had to compete for a place in the Luxury House, which was won by Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, and Hema Chaudhary.

Week 3: The third week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the introduction of the wildcard entrants Aari Arjunan and Thamarai Selvi. The contestants had to compete for the Star medal, which was won by Priyanka Deshpande.

Week 4: The fourth week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the contestants competing for the Cursed Stone. The Cursed Stone was won by Raju Jeyamohan.

Week 5: The fifth week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the contestants competing for the gold stars. The gold stars were won by Abhinay Vaddi.

Week 6: The sixth week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the contestants competing for the Bigg Boss Jail. The Bigg Boss Jail was won by Kiran.

Week 7: The seventh week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the contestants competing for the final week's nomination. The contestants who were nominated for eviction were Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, Hema Chaudhary, Priyanka Deshpande, and Raju Jeyamohan.

Week 8: The eighth week of Bigg Boss season 7 started with the contestants competing for the final week's nomination. The contestants who were nominated for eviction were Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, Hema Chaudhary, Priyanka Deshpande, and Raju Jeyamohan.

Nomination table

The nomination table for Bigg Boss season 7 was as follows:

| Week | Nominated Contestants | Evicted Contestant |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Week 1 | Priyanka Deshpande, Aari Arjunan, Thamarai Selvi | Aari Arjunan |
| Week 2 | Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, Hema Chaudhary | Thamarai Selvi |
| Week 3 | Priyanka Deshpande, Raju Jeyamohan | Priyanka Deshpande |
| Week 4 | Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, Hema Chaudhary | Kiran |
| Week 5 | Raju Jeyamohan, Nishanth | Raju Jeyamohan |
| Week 6 | Abhinay Vaddi, Archana Chandhoke, Hema Chaudhary | Archana Chandhoke |
| Week 7 | Priyanka Deshpande, Abhinay Vaddi, Hema Chaudhary | Hema Chaudhary |
| Week 8 | Abhinay Vaddi, Priyanka Deshpande | Abhinay Vaddi |

References

External links

* Bigg Boss Season 7 on Star Vijay
* Bigg Boss Season 7 on Hotstar

article:
**Constructive Set Theory**

Constructive set theory is a branch of mathematics that focuses on the study of sets and their properties using constructive logic. This approach emphasizes the importance of explicitly defining mathematical objects and operations, rather than relying on abstract axioms or non-constructive proofs. Constructive set theory has its roots in the ideas of L.E.J. Brouwer and has been developed further by mathematicians such as Errett Bishop and Vladimir Voevodsky.

**Introduction**

Traditional set theory, as developed by Georg Cantor and Ernst Zermelo, relies heavily on non-constructive principles such as the axiom of choice and the law of excluded middle. These principles allow for the existence of sets with arbitrary properties, but they can also lead to inconsistencies and paradoxes. In contrast, constructive set theory seeks to provide a more rigorous and explicit foundation for mathematics, by focusing on the constructive aspects of set theory.

**Constructive Outlook**

### Preliminary on the use of Intuitionistic Logic

Intuitionistic logic is a formal system that differs from classical logic in several key ways. In intuitionistic logic, the law of excluded middle is not assumed to be true, and instead, the truth of a statement is determined by its constructive proof. This means that a statement is considered true only if there exists a constructive proof of its truth, rather than simply assuming it to be true by default.

### Imposed Restrictions on a Set Theory

Constructive set theory imposes several restrictions on the set theory, in order to ensure that it is constructive. For example, the axiom of choice is not assumed to be true, and instead, the existence of a choice function is proven constructively. Additionally, the law of excluded middle is not assumed to be true, and instead, the truth of a statement is determined by its constructive proof.

### Metalogic

Metalogic is the study of the logical properties of formal systems, including constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, metalogic is used to study the constructive aspects of the theory, such as the existence of constructive proofs and the properties of constructive sets.

### Anti-Classical Principles

Anti-classical principles are principles that are not accepted in constructive set theory. For example, the law of excluded middle is an anti-classical principle, as it is not assumed to be true in constructive set theory. Other anti-classical principles include the axiom of choice and the law of the excluded middle.

**History and Overview**

### Models

Models of constructive set theory are formal systems that satisfy the axioms of constructive set theory. There are several models of constructive set theory, including the constructive Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory and the intuitionistic Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory.

**Notation**

### Language

The language of constructive set theory is based on a formal system that includes a set of axioms and a set of rules for forming proofs. The language is used to express mathematical statements and to prove theorems.

### Variables

Variables are symbols that are used to represent mathematical objects. In constructive set theory, variables are often used to represent sets and functions.

### Classes

Classes are sets of sets. In constructive set theory, classes are often used to represent sets of sets that satisfy certain properties.

### Extensional Equivalence

Extensional equivalence is a relation between sets that is based on their extension, rather than their intension. In constructive set theory, extensional equivalence is used to define the notion of equality between sets.

**Subtheories of ZF**

### Equality

Equality is a relation between sets that is based on their extension. In constructive set theory, equality is defined using the notion of extensional equivalence.

#### Alternative Approaches

There are several alternative approaches to defining equality in constructive set theory, including the use of intensional equivalence and the use of a different notion of equality.

### Merging Sets

Merging sets is the process of combining two sets into a single set. In constructive set theory, merging sets is used to define the notion of union.

### Set Existence

Set existence is the statement that a set exists. In constructive set theory, set existence is proven using the axiom of choice.

### BCST

BCST is a subtheory of constructive set theory that includes the axioms of choice and the axiom of replacement. BCST is used to define the notion of a universal set.

#### Separation

Separation is the process of defining a subset of a set using a property. In constructive set theory, separation is used to define the notion of a subset.

#### No Universal Set

No universal set is the statement that there is no set that contains all sets. In constructive set theory, no universal set is proven using the axiom of choice.

#### Predicativity

Predicativity is the property of a set that is defined using a property. In constructive set theory, predicativity is used to define the notion of a subset.

#### Replacement

Replacement is the process of defining a set using a function. In constructive set theory, replacement is used to define the notion of a subset.

#### Hereditarily Finite Sets

Hereditarily finite sets are sets that are defined using a finite sequence of functions. In constructive set theory, hereditarily finite sets are used to define the notion of a finite set.

### ECST

ECST is a subtheory of constructive set theory that includes the axioms of choice and the axiom of replacement. ECST is used to define the notion of a weakly infinite set.

#### Weaker Formulations of Infinity

Weaker formulations of infinity are statements that are weaker than the axiom of infinity. In constructive set theory, weaker formulations of infinity are used to define the notion of a finite set.

#### Number Bounds

Number bounds are statements that are used to define the notion of a finite set. In constructive set theory, number bounds are used to define the notion of a finite set.

#### Moderate Induction in ECST

Moderate induction is the process of defining a function using a property. In constructive set theory, moderate induction is used to define the notion of a finite set.

### Functions

#### General Note on Programs and Functions

A program is a sequence of instructions that is used to compute a function. In constructive set theory, programs are used to define the notion of a function.

#### Total Functional Relations

Total functional relations are relations between sets that are used to define the notion of a function. In constructive set theory, total functional relations are used to define the notion of a function.

#### Finitude

Finitude is the property of a set that is defined using a finite sequence of functions. In constructive set theory, finitude is used to define the notion of a finite set.

#### Infinitude

Infinitude is the property of a set that is defined using an infinite sequence of functions. In constructive set theory, infinitude is used to define the notion of an infinite set.

#### Characteristic Functions

Characteristic functions are functions that are used to define the notion of a subset. In constructive set theory, characteristic functions are used to define the notion of a subset.

#### Witness of Apartness

Witness of apartness is the statement that two sets are disjoint. In constructive set theory, witness of apartness is used to define the notion of a subset.

#### Computable Sets

Computable sets are sets that are defined using a computable function. In constructive set theory, computable sets are used to define the notion of a set.

#### Boundedness Criteria

Boundedness criteria are statements that are used to define the notion of a set. In constructive set theory, boundedness criteria are used to define the notion of a set.

## Choice Functions

### Diaconescu's Theorem

Diaconescu's theorem is the statement that the axiom of choice implies the law of excluded middle. In constructive set theory, Diaconescu's theorem is used to show that the axiom of choice is not constructively valid.

### Analysis of Diaconescu's Theorem

The analysis of Diaconescu's theorem is the study of the statement that the axiom of choice implies the law of excluded middle. In constructive set theory, the analysis of Diaconescu's theorem is used to show that the axiom of choice is not constructively valid.

### Regularity Implies PEM

Regularity implies PEM is the statement that regularity implies the law of excluded middle. In constructive set theory, regularity implies PEM is used to show that regularity is not constructively valid.

## Arithmetic

### Arithmetic Functions from Recursion

Arithmetic functions from recursion are functions that are defined using recursion. In constructive set theory, arithmetic functions from recursion are used to define the notion of an arithmetic function.

### Recursion from Set Theory Axioms

Recursion from set theory axioms is the process of defining a function using recursive axioms. In constructive set theory, recursion from set theory axioms is used to define the notion of a function.

### Induction Without Infinite Sets

Induction without infinite sets is the process of defining a function using induction without the axiom of infinity. In constructive set theory, induction without infinite sets is used to define the notion of a function.

## Exponentiation

### Unions and Countability

Unions and countability are statements that are used to define the notion of a set. In constructive set theory, unions and countability are used to define the notion of a set.

### The Class of All Subsets of a Set

The class of all subsets of a set is the set of all subsets of a given set. In constructive set theory, the class of all subsets of a set is used to define the notion of a set.

### Category and Type Theoretic Notions

Category and type theoretic notions are statements that are used to define the notion of a set. In constructive set theory, category and type theoretic notions are used to define the notion of a set.

### Metalogic

Metalogic is the study of the logical properties of formal systems, including constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, metalogic is used to study the constructive aspects of the theory.

## Analysis

### Topology

Topology is the study of the properties of sets that are preserved under continuous functions. In constructive set theory, topology is used to define the notion of a topological space.

### Cauchy Sequences

Cauchy sequences are sequences of real numbers that converge to a limit. In constructive set theory, Cauchy sequences are used to define the notion of a real number.

### Cauchy Reals

Cauchy reals are real numbers that are defined using Cauchy sequences. In constructive set theory, Cauchy reals are used to define the notion of a real number.

### Towards the Dedekind Reals

Towards the Dedekind reals is the process of defining a real number using Dedekind cuts. In constructive set theory, towards the Dedekind reals is used to define the notion of a real number.

### Constructive Schools

Constructive schools are schools of thought that emphasize the importance of constructive mathematics. In constructive set theory, constructive schools are used to define the notion of a constructive school.

### Indecomposability

Indecomposability is the property of a set that cannot be decomposed into smaller sets. In constructive set theory, indecomposability is used to define the notion of a set.

## Non-Constructive Principles

### Infinite Trees

Infinite trees are trees that have an infinite number of nodes. In constructive set theory, infinite trees are used to define the notion of a non-constructive principle.

## Induction

### Mathematical Induction

Mathematical induction is the process of defining a function using induction. In constructive set theory, mathematical induction is used to define the notion of a function.

### Set Induction

Set induction is the process of defining a set using induction. In constructive set theory, set induction is used to define the notion of a set.

### Metalogic

Metalogic is the study of the logical properties of formal systems, including constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, metalogic is used to study the constructive aspects of the theory.

### Relation to ZF

Relation to ZF is the study of the relationship between constructive set theory and Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. In constructive set theory, relation to ZF is used to define the notion of a constructive set theory.

## Strong Collection

### Metalogic

Metalogic is the study of the logical properties of formal systems, including constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, metalogic is used to study the constructive aspects of the theory.

## Constructive Zermelo–Fraenkel

### Binary Refinement

Binary refinement is the process of defining a set using a binary relation. In constructive set theory, binary refinement is used to define the notion of a set.

### Subset Collection

Subset collection is the process of collecting a subset of a set. In constructive set theory, subset collection is used to define the notion of a subset.

### Fullness

Fullness is the property of a set that is full of elements. In constructive set theory, fullness is used to define the notion of a set.

## Metalogic of CZF

### Unprovable Claims

Unprovable claims are statements that are not provable in constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, unprovable claims are used to define the notion of a unprovable claim.

### Ordinal Analysis

Ordinal analysis is the study of the ordinal numbers in constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, ordinal analysis is used to define the notion of an ordinal number.

### Models

Models of constructive set theory are formal systems that satisfy the axioms of constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, models are used to define the notion of a model.

### Breaking with ZF

Breaking with ZF is the process of deviating from Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. In constructive set theory, breaking with ZF is used to define the notion of a constructive set theory.

## Intuitionistic Zermelo–Fraenkel

### Metalogic

Metalogic is the study of the logical properties of formal systems, including constructive set theory. In constructive set theory, metalogic is used to study the constructive aspects of the theory.

## Intuitionistic Z

Intuitionistic Z is a subtheory of constructive set theory that includes the axioms of Zermelo. In constructive set theory, intuitionistic Z is used to define the notion of a set.

## Intuitionistic KP

Intuitionistic KP is a subtheory of constructive set theory that includes the axioms of Kripke-Platek. In constructive set theory, intuitionistic KP is used to define the notion of a set.

# Sorted Theories

## Constructive Set Theory

Constructive set theory is a branch of mathematics that focuses on the study of sets and their properties using constructive logic. In constructive set theory, sets are defined using constructive axioms and theorems.

## Bishop Style Set Theory

Bishop style set theory is a subtheory of constructive set theory that emphasizes the importance of constructive mathematics. In Bishop style set theory, sets are defined using constructive axioms and theorems.

## Category Theories

Category theories are a branch of mathematics that studies the properties of sets and functions using category theory. In category theories, sets and functions are defined using category axioms and theorems.

article:
**Rock-climbing equipment**

Rock-climbing equipment is a collection of tools and gear used by climbers to ascend, descend, and protect themselves while engaging in the sport of rock climbing. The equipment used in rock climbing has evolved significantly over the years, from simple ropes and pitons to advanced, high-tech devices that provide greater safety and flexibility.

**Use and certification**

The use of rock-climbing equipment is subject to certain guidelines and regulations to ensure safety and effectiveness. Climbers are required to follow established protocols and guidelines when using this equipment, and manufacturers must adhere to strict standards and testing procedures to ensure the quality and reliability of their products.

### Type of climbing

Rock-climbing equipment is used in various types of climbing, including:

* **Top-rope climbing**: This type of climbing involves attaching the rope to an anchor at the top of the climb and climbing up to a lower anchor, where the rope is then clipped to a carabiner and belayed back down.
* **Lead climbing**: This type of climbing involves attaching the rope to a carabiner on the climber's harness and clipping the rope to bolts or other anchors as the climber ascends.
* **Bouldering**: This type of climbing involves short, low-level climbs without the use of ropes or harnesses.

### Certification

Rock-climbing equipment is certified by organizations such as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH). Certification ensures that the equipment meets strict standards for safety, durability, and performance.

**Ropes and slings**

Ropes and slings are essential components of rock-climbing equipment, providing a safe and secure means of ascending and descending the rock face.

### Ropes

Ropes are made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and Kevlar. The most common type of rope used in rock climbing is the dynamic rope, which is designed to stretch and absorb shock in the event of a fall. Dynamic ropes are typically made from nylon or polyester and have a diameter of 10-11 mm.

### Slings

Slings are used to create temporary anchors, attaching the rope to a karabiner or other anchor point. Slings can be made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and webbing.

### Cords

Cords are used in conjunction with slings to create a more secure anchor point. Cords can be made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and Kevlar.

**Rope connectors**

Rope connectors are used to attach the rope to a carabiner or other anchor point.

### Carabiners

Carabiners are small metal clips that are used to attach the rope to a carabiner or other anchor point. Carabiners are designed to withstand heavy loads and are typically made from aluminum or steel.

### Harnesses

Harnesses are worn by climbers to attach the rope to the carabiner. Harnesses are typically made from nylon or polyester and have a waist belt and leg loops.

### Lanyards

Lanyards are used to create a personal anchor system (PAS) by attaching the rope to a carabiner on the climber's harness. Lanyards can be made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and webbing.

### Personal anchor systems

Personal anchor systems (PAS) are used to create a secure anchor point by attaching the rope to a carabiner on the climber's harness and clipping the rope to a bolt or other anchor.

**Quickdraws**

Quickdraws are used to create a quick and easy way to attach the rope to a carabiner or other anchor point. Quickdraws consist of a carabiner attached to a rope and a second carabiner attached to the end of the rope.

**Rope devices**

Rope devices are used to control the rate of ascent or descent of the rope.

### Ascenders

Ascenders are used to control the rate of ascent of the rope. Ascenders are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and Kevlar.

### Belay devices

Belay devices are used to control the rate of descent of the rope. Belay devices are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and steel.

### Descenders

Descenders are used to control the rate of descent of the rope. Descenders are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and Kevlar.

### Self-locking devices

Self-locking devices are used to prevent the rope from descending too quickly. Self-locking devices are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and steel.

**Protection devices**

Protection devices are used to create temporary or fixed anchors on the rock face.

### Temporary

Temporary anchors are used to create a secure anchor point while climbing.

### Active

Active anchors are used to create a secure anchor point while climbing and are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and webbing.

### Passive

Passive anchors are used to create a secure anchor point while climbing and are typically made from a variety of materials, including nylon, polyester, and Kevlar.

### Fixed

Fixed anchors are used to create a permanent anchor point and are typically made from a variety of materials, including steel, aluminum, and concrete.

**Aid equipment**

Aid equipment is used to assist climbers in ascending the rock face.

* **Aid climbing**: This type of climbing involves using equipment such as ladders, ascenders, and pitons to assist in ascending the rock face.
* **Aid equipment**: This type of equipment is used to assist climbers in ascending the rock face and includes items such as ladders, ascenders, and pitons.

**Clothing equipment**

Clothing equipment is used to protect the climber from the elements and provide comfort while climbing.

* **Climbing shoes**: These are specialized shoes designed to provide a secure fit and grip on the rock face.
* **Climbing gloves**: These are specialized gloves designed to provide a secure grip and protection for the hands.
* **Climbing harness**: This is a specialized harness designed to provide a secure fit and attachment point for the rope.

**Miscellaneous equipment**

Miscellaneous equipment is used for a variety of purposes while climbing.

* **Headlamp**: This is a light source used to illuminate the rock face in low-light conditions.
* **First aid kit**: This is a kit used to treat minor injuries and illnesses.
* **Climbing rope bag**: This is a bag used to store and transport climbing equipment.

**Training equipment**

Training equipment is used to help climbers develop and improve their climbing skills.

* **Indoor climbing wall**: This is a wall used to practice climbing techniques and build strength and endurance.
* **Climbing simulator**: This is a device used to simulate climbing conditions and practice techniques.
* **Climbing holds**: These are devices used to create artificial climbing holds for training and practice.

**See also**

* **Manufacturers**: This section lists manufacturers of rock-climbing equipment.
* **Types**: This section lists different types of rock-climbing equipment.

**References**

* **Further reading**: This section lists additional resources for learning more about rock-climbing equipment.

**External links**

* **Climbing equipment manufacturers**: This section lists links to manufacturers of rock-climbing equipment.
* **Climbing equipment retailers**: This section lists links to retailers of rock-climbing equipment.

article:
**2023 Indian Wrestlers' Protest**

The 2023 Indian wrestlers' protest was a series of demonstrations and protests organized by Indian wrestlers in response to alleged police brutality and corruption within the Indian wrestling community. The protests began in February 2023 and gained national attention, leading to widespread criticism and condemnation of the Indian government's handling of the situation.

**Background**

The Indian wrestling community has a long history of producing world-class wrestlers, with several Indian wrestlers winning Olympic medals and international tournaments. However, in recent years, the community has been plagued by allegations of corruption, nepotism, and favoritism. Many wrestlers have claimed that they have been subjected to harassment, intimidation, and physical violence by officials and coaches.

**Initial Investigation**

In January 2023, several Indian wrestlers, including Olympic medalists Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, came forward with allegations of police brutality and corruption within the Indian wrestling community. The wrestlers claimed that they had been subjected to harassment and intimidation by officials and coaches, and that they had been denied access to fair trials and justice.

The Indian government responded to the allegations by launching an investigation into the matter. The investigation was led by the Delhi Police, which is responsible for maintaining law and order in the national capital. However, the investigation was widely criticized for being inadequate and biased, with many accusing the police of trying to cover up the allegations.

**Protest Overview**

The protests began on February 19, 2023, when a group of Indian wrestlers, including Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, gathered at the Jantar Mantar in New Delhi to demand justice and accountability from the Indian government. The protesters, who were mostly wrestlers and their supporters, held placards and banners and shouted slogans demanding the resignation of the Indian government and the establishment of an independent inquiry into the allegations.

The protests quickly gained momentum, with more and more wrestlers and supporters joining in. The protesters marched through the streets of New Delhi, holding rallies and demonstrations in various parts of the city.

**FIR Registration and Supreme Court Intervention**

On February 20, 2023, the Delhi Police registered an FIR (First Information Report) against several Indian wrestlers, including Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, on charges of rioting and obstructing public servants from performing their duty. The FIR was widely criticized as being biased and arbitrary, with many accusing the police of trying to silence the wrestlers.

The Indian Supreme Court intervened in the matter on February 22, 2023, staying the FIR registration and directing the police to investigate the allegations of corruption and police brutality. The court also directed the government to establish an independent inquiry into the allegations.

**Jantar Mantar Clash**

On February 23, 2023, a clash broke out between the protesters and the police at the Jantar Mantar in New Delhi. The protesters, who were demanding justice and accountability, were met with baton charges and tear gas by the police. Several protesters were injured in the clash, and many were arrested.

**Formation of SIT and Questioning of Witnesses**

In response to the Supreme Court's order, the Indian government formed a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to investigate the allegations of corruption and police brutality. The SIT, which was headed by a senior police officer, began questioning witnesses and gathering evidence.

However, the SIT's investigation was widely criticized for being slow and inadequate, with many accusing the government of trying to cover up the allegations.

**New Parliament House March and Detainment**

On February 25, 2023, the protesters marched to the New Parliament House in New Delhi, demanding justice and accountability from the Indian government. However, the police detained several protesters, including Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, on charges of rioting and obstructing public servants.

**Meeting with Sports Minister and Filing of Chargesheet**

On February 27, 2023, the protesters met with the Indian Sports Minister, Anurag Thakur, to demand justice and accountability. However, the meeting was widely criticized for being inadequate and unsatisfactory.

On February 28, 2023, the SIT filed a chargesheet against several Indian wrestlers, including Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, on charges of rioting and obstructing public servants. The chargesheet was widely criticized for being biased and arbitrary.

**Aftermath**

The protests continued for several weeks, with the wrestlers and their supporters demanding justice and accountability from the Indian government. However, the government's response to the allegations was widely criticized for being inadequate and biased.

In the aftermath of the protests, several Indian wrestlers, including Vinesh Phogat and Bajrang Punia, were denied entry to the Indian wrestling team for the Commonwealth Games. The decision was widely criticized as being politically motivated.

**Reactions**

**Domestic**

The protests were widely criticized by domestic politicians and commentators, who accused the wrestlers of being irresponsible and attention-seeking. However, many also criticized the government's response to the allegations as being inadequate and biased.

**Criticism**

The protests were also criticized for being a distraction from more important issues facing the country. However, many argued that the allegations of corruption and police brutality were serious and warranted attention.

**International**

The protests were widely reported in international media, with many countries expressing concern over the allegations of corruption and police brutality.

**United World Wrestling**

The United World Wrestling (UWW), the international governing body of wrestling, expressed concern over the allegations of corruption and police brutality. The UWW called for an independent inquiry into the allegations and urged the Indian government to take action to address the situation.

**International Olympic Committee**

The International Olympic Committee (IOC) also expressed concern over the allegations of corruption and police brutality. The IOC called for an independent inquiry into the allegations and urged the Indian government to take action to address the situation.

**Parliamentarians**

Several parliamentarians from around the world expressed concern over the allegations of corruption and police brutality. They called for an independent inquiry into the allegations and urged the Indian government to take action to address the situation.

**Media Coverage**

The protests were widely covered in the media, with many news outlets reporting on the allegations of corruption and police brutality. However, some media outlets were criticized for being biased and sensationalistic in their reporting.

**Impact**

The protests had a significant impact on the Indian wrestling community, with many wrestlers and their supporters demanding justice and accountability from the Indian government. However, the government's response to the allegations was widely criticized for being inadequate and biased.

The protests also had a significant impact on the Indian sports community, with many athletes and coaches expressing concern over the allegations of corruption and police brutality.

article:
**2023 FIVB Women's Volleyball Nations League**

The 2023 FIVB Women's Volleyball Nations League was the 5th edition of the annual international women's volleyball tournament organized by the Fédération Internationale de Volleyball (FIVB). The tournament took place from May 16 to June 25, 2023, with 16 teams competing in a round-robin format followed by a final round.

**Qualification**

The qualification process for the 2023 FIVB Women's Volleyball Nations League involved 16 teams competing in a preliminary round. The teams were divided into 4 pools, with the top 4 teams from each pool advancing to the final round.

**Format**

The 2023 FIVB Women's Volleyball Nations League featured a unique format. The tournament was divided into two rounds: the preliminary round and the final round.

### Preliminary round

The preliminary round took place from May 16 to May 21, 2023. The 16 teams were divided into 4 pools of 4 teams each. Each team played the other teams in its pool once, resulting in a total of 3 matches per team.

### Final round

The final round took place from May 23 to June 25, 2023. The top 4 teams from each pool advanced to the final round, where they competed in a knockout format.

**Pool composition**

The 16 teams were divided into 4 pools of 4 teams each. The pools were as follows:

* Pool 1: Brazil, Italy, Japan, and South Korea
* Pool 2: China, Dominican Republic, Poland, and Turkey
* Pool 3: Russia, Serbia, Thailand, and Belgium
* Pool 4: United States, Germany, Netherlands, and Bulgaria

* June 25: Final standing and awards ceremony

**Pool standing procedure**

The pool standing procedure was as follows:

* The team with the most wins in the preliminary round advanced to the final round.

article:
2022 Vietnam Open

The 2022 Vietnam Open was a badminton tournament that took place in Hanoi, Vietnam, from April 5 to April 10, 2022. The tournament was part of the BWF World Tour Super 100 category.

Venue
--------

The 2022 Vietnam Open was held at the Nguyen Du Cultural Sports Club in Hanoi, Vietnam.

Point distribution
-----------------

The point distribution for the 2022 Vietnam Open was as follows:

* Men's singles: 1,000 points for the winner, 700 points for the runner-up, and 320-150 points for the semifinalists and quarterfinalists, respectively.
* Women's singles: 1,000 points for the winner, 700 points for the runner-up, and 320-150 points for the semifinalists and quarterfinalists, respectively.
* Men's doubles: 1,000 points for the winner, 700 points for the runner-up, and 320-150 points for the semifinalists and quarterfinalists, respectively.
* Women's doubles: 1,000 points for the winner, 700 points for the runner-up, and 320-150 points for the semifinalists and quarterfinalists, respectively.
* Mixed doubles: 1,000 points for the winner, 700 points for the runner-up, and 320-150 points for the semifinalists and quarterfinalists, respectively.

Prize pool
----------

The 2022 Vietnam Open had a total prize pool of $150,000.

Men's singles
--------------

The men's singles event was contested by 64 players, with the following seeds:

1.  Lee Chong Wei (Malaysia)
2.  Kanta Tsuneyama (Japan)
3.  Anthony Ginting (Indonesia)

5.  Ng Ka Long Angus (Hong Kong)

7.  Kunlavut Vitidsarn (Thailand)

The final was contested between Lee Chong Wei and Anthony Ginting, with Lee Chong Wei winning in straight sets, 21-14, 21-18.

article:
Febrile seizure
================

A febrile seizure is a convulsion or seizure that occurs in association with a fever, typically in children between the ages of six months and five years. These seizures are most commonly caused by a rapid increase in body temperature, often due to a viral or bacterial infection.

Signs and symptoms
------------------

### Types

Febrile seizures can take several forms, including:

*   **Generalized tonic-clonic seizures**: These are the most common type of febrile seizure and are characterized by a loss of consciousness, muscle stiffness, and convulsions.
*   **Focal seizures**: These seizures are limited to a specific area of the brain and can cause a range of symptoms, including numbness, tingling, and weakness.
*   **Myoclonic seizures**: These seizures cause sudden, brief muscle contractions that can be accompanied by a loss of consciousness.

Causes
-------

Febrile seizures are most commonly caused by a rapid increase in body temperature, often due to a viral or bacterial infection. Some common causes of febrile seizures include:

*   **Viral infections**: Such as influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and rotavirus.
*   **Bacterial infections**: Such as ear infections, urinary tract infections, and pneumonia.
*   **Other causes**: Such as immunizations, allergic reactions, and certain medications.

Mechanism
----------

The exact mechanism of febrile seizures is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve a combination of factors, including:

*   **Increased body temperature**: A rapid increase in body temperature can cause changes in the brain's chemistry and function, leading to a seizure.
*   **Release of neurotransmitters**: The release of neurotransmitters, such as dopamine and serotonin, can contribute to the development of a seizure.
*   **Abnormal brain activity**: Abnormal brain activity, such as changes in brain wave patterns, can contribute to the development of a seizure.

Diagnosis
----------

Diagnosing a febrile seizure can be challenging, as the symptoms can be similar to those of other conditions. However, a diagnosis can be made based on a combination of the following factors:

*   **Medical history**: A thorough medical history, including information about the child's previous medical conditions and allergies.
*   **Physical examination**: A physical examination, including a check for fever, muscle stiffness, and other symptoms.
*   **Diagnostic tests**: Diagnostic tests, such as blood tests and imaging studies, may be ordered to rule out other conditions.

Prevention
----------

While it is not possible to completely prevent febrile seizures, there are some steps that can be taken to reduce the risk:

*   **Maintaining a safe environment**: Ensuring that the child's environment is safe and free from hazards can help to prevent injuries during a seizure.
*   **Providing proper medical care**: Providing proper medical care, including medication and other treatments, can help to reduce the risk of febrile seizures.
*   **Staying informed**: Staying informed about the child's medical condition and the latest research on febrile seizures can help to provide the best possible care.

Treatment
----------

Treatment for febrile seizures typically involves a combination of the following:

*   **Medications**: Medications, such as anticonvulsants and anti-inflammatory agents, may be prescribed to help control the seizure and reduce the risk of future seizures.
*   **Fluid replacement**: Fluid replacement, such as IV fluids, may be necessary to help replace lost fluids and electrolytes.
*   **Monitoring**: Monitoring the child's vital signs and neurological status can help to ensure that the seizure is controlled and that the child is safe.

Prognosis
----------

The prognosis for children with febrile seizures is generally good, with most children making a full recovery and having no long-term effects. However, some children may experience:

*   **Seizure recurrence**: Some children may experience recurrent febrile seizures, which can increase the risk of developing epilepsy.
*   **Developmental delays**: Some children may experience developmental delays or other cognitive impairments due to the seizure.
*   **Emotional and behavioral problems**: Some children may experience emotional and behavioral problems, such as anxiety and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, due to the seizure.

Epidemiology
------------

Febrile seizures are a common condition, affecting approximately 2-5% of children between the ages of six months and five years. The risk of febrile seizures is higher in children with:

*   **Family history**: Children with a family history of febrile seizures are at increased risk.
*   **Previous medical conditions**: Children with previous medical conditions, such as ear infections and urinary tract infections, are at increased risk.
*   **Age**: Children between the ages of six months and five years are at increased risk.

References
----------

This article has been written to provide factual and informative content about febrile seizures.

article:
Pandya Store

Pandya Store is an Indian Hindi-language television drama series that premiered on 25 January 2021 on Star Bharat and is produced by Bodhi Tree Multimedia and Shashi Sumeet Productions. The show revolves around the lives of the Pandya family, their relationships, and the challenges they face.

Premise

The series is set in a small town in India and follows the lives of the Pandya family, who own a small store in the town. The show explores the themes of love, family, relationships, and the struggles of living in a small town. The series aims to showcase the complexities of human relationships and the challenges that come with them.

Plot

The show begins with the introduction of the Pandya family, consisting of Krishna (played by Kiran Kumar), Nandini (played by Kanika Maheshwari), and their two sons, Shiva (played by Anirudh Dave) and Om (played by Shivang Jadhav). The family is shown to be living a happy and content life, with Shiva and Om being the center of attention.

10 years later

The story takes a turn 10 years later, when Shiva and Om return to their hometown after completing their education. They are shown to be ambitious and eager to make a name for themselves, but their plans are soon put on hold when they are forced to return to their hometown and help their father with the family business.

Shiva, who is the elder of the two brothers, is shown to be responsible and mature, while Om is depicted as younger and more carefree. Their relationship is shown to be complex, with Shiva often taking on the role of a mentor and Om struggling with feelings of inadequacy.

7 years later

The story jumps forward again, this time 7 years, and shows the Pandya family facing new challenges. Shiva has gotten married and is now a father, while Om is still single and struggling to find his place in the world. The family is shown to be facing financial difficulties, and Krishna is forced to think outside the box to save the family business.

Meanwhile, Shiva's wife, Dhara (played by Akanksha Juneja), is introduced, and her character is shown to be strong-willed and independent. She is shown to be a good influence on Shiva and helps him to see things from a different perspective.

15 years later

The story takes another jump forward, this time 15 years, and shows the Pandya family facing their biggest challenge yet. Krishna has passed away, and the family is left to pick up the pieces. Shiva and Om are shown to be struggling to come to terms with their loss, and the family is forced to come together to support each other.

The story also introduces a new character, Alisha (played by Aashna Mukherjee), who is shown to be a young and ambitious woman. She is introduced as a love interest for Om, but her character is also shown to be complex, with a dark past and a desire for revenge.

Cast

Main

* Kiran Kumar as Krishna Pandya
* Kanika Maheshwari as Nandini Pandya
* Anirudh Dave as Shiva Pandya
* Shivang Jadhav as Om Pandya
* Akanksha Juneja as Dhara Pandya
* Aashna Mukherjee as Alisha
* Bhavna Balsara as Chandrika Pandya

Recurring

* Neena Kulkarni as Radhika
* Shakti Arora as Ravi
* Aashna Mukherjee as Alisha

Special appearances

* Manasi Parekh Gohil as Aisha
* Manish Khanna as Rajiv

Production

Development

The show was developed by Bodhi Tree Multimedia and Shashi Sumeet Productions, with a team of experienced writers and directors. The show was created to explore the complexities of human relationships and the challenges that come with them.

Casting

The casting process for the show was rigorous, with the producers looking for actors who could bring depth and nuance to their characters. The cast includes a mix of experienced and new actors, with each bringing their own unique perspective to the show.

Filming

The show was filmed on location in Mumbai and other parts of India. The production team used a combination of studio and on-location filming to bring the show to life.

Release

The show premiered on 25 January 2021 on Star Bharat, with a special episode to introduce the characters and the story. The show has since become a regular fixture on the channel, with new episodes airing every week.

Broadcast

The show is broadcast on Star Bharat, Monday to Saturday, at 8:30 pm. The show is also available to stream on the channel's website and mobile app.

Cancellation

The show has been renewed for multiple seasons, with the latest season airing in 2022. The show has been well-received by audiences and critics alike, and it continues to be a popular fixture on Indian television.

Television specials

Pyar Ka Pehla Nasha (2021)

The show's first television special, Pyar Ka Pehla Nasha, aired in 2021. The special episode explored the backstory of the Pandya family and their relationships with each other.

Ravivaar With Star Parivaar (2022)

The show's second television special, Ravivaar With Star Parivaar, aired in 2022. The special episode featured the cast and crew of the show, as well as other celebrities from the Indian television industry.

Reception

Critical reception

The show has received widespread critical acclaim for its portrayal of complex relationships and its exploration of the human condition. The show has been praised for its strong performances, engaging storyline, and well-developed characters.

Adaptations

The show has been adapted into several languages, including Hindi, Marathi, and Tamil. The show's success has also inspired spin-offs and related shows, including a web series and a film.

Soundtrack

The show's soundtrack has been composed by various artists, including Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy and Amaal Malik. The show's theme song, "Pandya Store", has become a popular anthem among fans of the show.

Awards and nominations

The show has won several awards, including the Indian Telly Award for Best Drama Series and the Star Guild Award for Best Drama Series. The show has also been nominated for several other awards, including the ITA Award for Best Drama Series and the Zee Gold Award for Best Drama Series.

**Green Party of California**

The Green Party of California is a state chapter of the Green Party of the United States. The party was founded in 1990 and is headquartered in Sacramento, California. It has approximately 80,000 registered members and has played a significant role in California politics.

**History**

### Qualifying for elections

The Green Party of California gained ballot status in 1992 after a successful petition drive. The party has maintained ballot status through subsequent elections. In 2014, the party qualified for the general election ballot by collecting signatures from voters.

### Electoral milestones

The Green Party of California has had several notable electoral successes. In 1994, the party's gubernatorial candidate, Dan Hamburg, won 7.4% of the vote in the general election. In 2000, the party's presidential candidate, Ralph Nader, won 3.4% of the vote in California. In 2010, the party's mayoral candidate, Jill Reed, won 13.5% of the vote in the general election in Chico, California.

### Top-two primaries

In 2010, California voters approved Proposition 14, which established a top-two primary system. Under this system, the top two candidates in a primary election, regardless of party affiliation, advance to the general election. The Green Party of California has opposed the top-two primary system, arguing that it reduces voter choice and hinders the ability of minor parties to participate in the electoral process.

**Platform**

The Green Party of California's platform is based on the principles of environmental sustainability, social justice, and non-violence. The party's platform includes positions on issues such as:

* Climate change and energy policy
* Economic justice and workers' rights
* Healthcare and social services
* Education and human rights
* Peace and non-violence

The party's platform is guided by the principles of ecological wisdom, social justice, and grassroots democracy.

**Organization**

### Membership

The Green Party of California has approximately 80,000 registered members. Membership is open to individuals who support the party's principles and platform. Members can participate in local and state party activities, attend party events, and vote on party decisions.

### Local chapters

The Green Party of California has local chapters throughout the state. These chapters are organized by county and are responsible for promoting the party's message, recruiting new members, and participating in local elections.

**Current elected officials**

The Green Party of California has several elected officials at the local and state level. These include:

### Mayoral offices

* Jill Reed, Mayor of Chico, California (2010-2012)
* Ryan Combs, Mayor of Sebastopol, California (2012-2014)
* Josh Stephens, Mayor of Sebastopol, California (2014-present)

### Municipal councils

* Tim Farrell, Councilmember, City of Chico, California (2012-present)
* Mark Wheett, Councilmember, Town of Villa Grande, California (2012-present)
* Anthony Ruffa, Councilmember, City of San Luis Obispo, California (2014-present)

**Election results**

### Presidential

The Green Party of California has participated in several presidential elections. In 2000, the party's presidential candidate, Ralph Nader, won 3.4% of the vote in California. In 2016, the party's presidential candidate, Jill Stein, won 1.5% of the vote in California.

### Gubernatorial

The Green Party of California has also participated in several gubernatorial elections. In 1994, the party's gubernatorial candidate, Dan Hamburg, won 7.4% of the vote in the general election.

### Election qualifying

To qualify for the general election ballot, the Green Party of California must collect signatures from voters. The party must collect signatures from at least 1% of the total number of registered voters in the state, or 65,000 signatures.

**Notable members**

The Green Party of California has several notable members, including:

* Dan Hamburg, former U.S. Representative and gubernatorial candidate
* Jill Stein, presidential candidate and physician
* Ryan Combs, former mayor of Sebastopol, California
* Tim Farrell, councilmember, City of Chico, California
* Mark Wheett, councilmember, Town of Villa Grande, California

**See also**

* Green Party of the United States
* California Democratic Party
* California Republican Party
* California Libertarian Party

**Adipurush**

Adipurush is an upcoming Indian epic action-adventure film written and directed by Om Raut. The film is a retelling of the ancient Indian epic, the Ramayana, with a unique visual and storytelling style. The film stars Ajay Devgn as Lord Rama, Saif Ali Khan as Ravana, and Kriti Sanon as Sita.

**Plot**

The film is a retelling of the Ramayana, with a focus on the story of Lord Rama, his wife Sita, and his battle against the demon king Ravana. The story begins with Lord Rama, the prince of Ayodhya, who is forced to leave his kingdom and go into exile for 14 years. Rama, accompanied by his wife Sita and brother Lakshmana, ventures into the forest, where they face numerous challenges and obstacles. Meanwhile, Ravana, the king of Lanka, kidnaps Sita and takes her to his kingdom, sparking a war between Rama and Ravana. The film follows the epic battle between good and evil, with Rama and his allies fighting to rescue Sita and defeat Ravana.

**Cast**

* Ajay Devgn as Lord Rama
* Saif Ali Khan as Ravana
* Kriti Sanon as Sita
* Sunny Singh as Lakshmana
* Nidhi Aggerwal as Mandodari
* Devdatta Nage as Hanuman

**Production**

### **Development**

The film was announced in 2018, with Om Raut directing and writing the screenplay. The film is produced by T-Series and Retrophiles in association with Ayush Mahesh Khedekar and Rajesh Bhatia. The film is a retelling of the Ramayana, with a unique visual and storytelling style.

### **Casting**

The casting for the film began in 2018, with Ajay Devgn signing on to play the role of Lord Rama. Saif Ali Khan was later cast as Ravana, and Kriti Sanon was cast as Sita. Sunny Singh was cast as Lakshmana, and Nidhi Aggerwal was cast as Mandodari. Devdatta Nage was cast as Hanuman.

### **Filming**

The filming for the film began in 2020 and wrapped up in 2022. The film was shot in several locations across India, including Mumbai, Ayodhya, and Nepal. The film's cinematography was handled by Vishal Rau, and the editing was done by Saurabh Saxena.

**Music**

The music for the film is composed by Ajay-Atul, with lyrics by Manoj Muntashir. The soundtrack features several songs, including "Jai Jai Jai Rama Rama", "Tere Bina", and "Sita". The music for the film was released in 2022, and it received positive reviews from critics.

**Marketing**

The marketing for the film began in 2022, with the release of the film's teaser and trailer. The teaser received over 100 million views on YouTube, and the trailer received over 50 million views. The film's posters were also released, featuring the lead actors in their roles. The marketing campaign for the film was handled by T-Series and Retrophiles.

**Release**

### **Theatrical**

The film is scheduled to release on January 12, 2024, in India and other countries. The film will be released in several languages, including Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, and Malayalam.

### **Home media**

The film will be released on home media platforms, including DVD, Blu-ray, and digital streaming services, after its theatrical run.

### **Game**

A video game based on the film is also in development, with a release date to be announced later.

**Reception**

### **Critical response**

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its visuals and action sequences, while others criticized its storytelling and pacing.

### **Box office**

The film is expected to gross over 500 crore at the box office, with a worldwide release.

**Controversies**

### **Allahabad High Court on Adipurush**

The Allahabad High Court issued a notice to the film's producers, urging them to ensure that the film does not distort the image of Lord Rama and the Ramayana.

### **Reactions after the teaser release**

The teaser for the film received mixed reactions from fans and critics, with some praising its visuals and others criticizing its storytelling.

### **Reactions on the film's posters**

The film's posters received mixed reactions from fans and critics, with some praising their design and others criticizing their content.

### **Dialogues of Adipurush**

The film's dialogues were criticized by some for being inaccurate and misrepresenting the Ramayana.

### **Backtracking and making contradictory statements**

The film's producers were accused of backtracking and making contradictory statements regarding the film's content and storyline.

### **Claiming that Lord Hanuman is 'not a god'**

The film's producers were accused of claiming that Lord Hanuman is 'not a god', which was seen as an attempt to downplay the character's importance in the Ramayana.

**Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel**

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (August 27, 1770 – November 14, 1831) was a German philosopher who is widely regarded as one of the most important figures in the history of philosophy. His philosophical system, which emphasizes the unity and absolute spirit, has had a profound impact on modern thought, influencing fields such as philosophy, theology, politics, and art.

**Life**

### Formative years

**Stuttgart, Tübingen, Berne, Frankfurt (1770–1800)**

Hegel was born in Stuttgart, Württemberg, Germany, to a family of civil servants. His father was a revenue officer, and the family moved to Württemberg when Hegel was a child. Hegel's early education took place in Stuttgart, where he excelled in languages, literature, and philosophy. In 1788, he enrolled in the University of Tübingen to study theology and philosophy. During his time at Tübingen, Hegel developed a strong interest in philosophy, particularly in the works of Immanuel Kant and Johann Gottlieb Fichte. In 1790, he moved to Berne, Switzerland, where he studied law and philosophy, and in 1793, he returned to Frankfurt, where he worked as a tutor and began to develop his own philosophical ideas.

### Career years

**Jena, Bamberg, Nuremberg (1801–1816)**

In 1801, Hegel moved to Jena, where he became a lecturer in philosophy at the University of Jena. During his time in Jena, Hegel developed his philosophical system, which emphasized the unity and absolute spirit. In 1807, he published his first major work, _The Phenomenology of Spirit_. In 1808, he moved to Bamberg, where he worked as a vice-rector of the Gymnasium, and in 1811, he returned to Nuremberg, where he worked as a editor and lecturer. In 1816, he moved to Heidelberg, where he became a professor of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg.

### Heidelberg, Berlin (1816–1831)

In 1816, Hegel moved to Heidelberg, where he became a professor of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg. During his time in Heidelberg, Hegel developed his philosophical system further, and in 1818, he published his _Lectures on the Philosophy of History_. In 1818, he moved to Berlin, where he became a professor of philosophy at the University of Berlin. In Berlin, Hegel became a prominent figure in intellectual circles, and his lectures were attended by many notable figures, including Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx. Hegel's time in Berlin was marked by his development of his philosophical system, particularly in his _Lectures on the Philosophy of History_ and his _Lectures on the Philosophy of Nature_.

**Influences**

Hegel's philosophical system was influenced by a wide range of thinkers, including Immanuel Kant, Johann Gottlieb Fichte, and Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling. He was also influenced by the French Revolution and the Enlightenment, which emphasized reason and individual rights. Hegel's thought was further influenced by his experiences as a professor in Jena, Heidelberg, and Berlin, where he interacted with many notable figures, including Friedrich Schiller and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.

**The Phenomenology of Spirit**

The _Phenomenology of Spirit_ is Hegel's first major work, published in 1807. The book is a comprehensive overview of his philosophical system, which emphasizes the unity and absolute spirit. The book is divided into ten chapters, each of which explores a different phase of the spirit's development. The book begins with the concept of consciousness and ends with the concept of absolute spirit. Throughout the book, Hegel argues that the spirit is a dynamic and self-conscious entity that develops through a series of stages, each of which is characterized by a greater degree of self-awareness and understanding.

**Philosophical system**

Hegel's philosophical system is a comprehensive and systematic approach to understanding reality. It is based on the idea that reality is a unified and coherent whole, which is structured by a series of dialectical relationships. The system is divided into three main parts: the science of logic, the philosophy of nature, and the philosophy of spirit.

### Science of Logic

The science of logic is the first part of Hegel's philosophical system. It is a comprehensive overview of the laws and principles that govern reality. The science of logic is divided into three main sections: the doctrine of being, the doctrine of essence, and the doctrine of the concept. The doctrine of being explores the fundamental principles of reality, including the concept of being and the concept of nothing. The doctrine of essence explores the relationships between being and essence, including the concept of identity and the concept of difference. The doctrine of the concept explores the relationships between being and essence, including the concept of unity and the concept of complexity.

### Philosophy of the real

The philosophy of the real is the second part of Hegel's philosophical system. It is a comprehensive overview of the natural world, including the laws and principles that govern it. The philosophy of the real is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of nature, the philosophy of mind, and the philosophy of spirit. The philosophy of nature explores the fundamental principles of the natural world, including the concept of space and the concept of time. The philosophy of mind explores the relationships between the mind and the natural world, including the concept of perception and the concept of cognition. The philosophy of spirit explores the relationships between the spirit and the natural world, including the concept of the self and the concept of the world.

### The Philosophy of Nature

The philosophy of nature is the first section of the philosophy of the real. It is a comprehensive overview of the natural world, including the laws and principles that govern it. The philosophy of nature is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of inorganic nature, the philosophy of organic nature, and the philosophy of the human spirit. The philosophy of inorganic nature explores the fundamental principles of the inorganic world, including the concept of space and the concept of time. The philosophy of organic nature explores the relationships between the inorganic and organic worlds, including the concept of life and the concept of death. The philosophy of the human spirit explores the relationships between the human spirit and the natural world, including the concept of the self and the concept of the world.

### The Philosophy of Spirit

The philosophy of spirit is the third part of Hegel's philosophical system. It is a comprehensive overview of the human spirit, including the laws and principles that govern it. The philosophy of spirit is divided into three main sections: subjective spirit, objective spirit, and absolute spirit.

#### Subjective spirit

Subjective spirit is the first section of the philosophy of spirit. It is a comprehensive overview of the individual's subjective experience, including the concept of self-consciousness and the concept of the self. Subjective spirit is divided into three main sections: the phenomenology of spirit, the psychology of spirit, and the anthropology of spirit. The phenomenology of spirit explores the fundamental principles of self-consciousness, including the concept of the self and the concept of the other. The psychology of spirit explores the relationships between the self and the external world, including the concept of perception and the concept of cognition. The anthropology of spirit explores the relationships between the self and the external world, including the concept of culture and the concept of history.

#### Objective spirit

Objective spirit is the second section of the philosophy of spirit. It is a comprehensive overview of the external world, including the laws and principles that govern it. Objective spirit is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of right, the philosophy of morality, and the philosophy of world history. The philosophy of right explores the fundamental principles of the external world, including the concept of property and the concept of contract. The philosophy of morality explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of duty and the concept of virtue. The philosophy of world history explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of history and the concept of culture.

#### Absolute spirit

Absolute spirit is the third section of the philosophy of spirit. It is a comprehensive overview of the absolute, including the laws and principles that govern it. Absolute spirit is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of art, the philosophy of religion, and the philosophy of absolute knowledge. The philosophy of art explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of beauty and the concept of truth. The philosophy of religion explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of God and the concept of salvation. The philosophy of absolute knowledge explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of knowledge and the concept of truth.

**Philosophy of art**

Hegel's philosophy of art is a comprehensive overview of the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of beauty and the concept of truth. The philosophy of art is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of beauty, the philosophy of the arts, and the philosophy of the absolute. The philosophy of beauty explores the fundamental principles of beauty, including the concept of form and the concept of content. The philosophy of the arts explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of music and the concept of dance. The philosophy of the absolute explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of the absolute and the concept of truth.

**Christianity**

Hegel's philosophy of Christianity is a comprehensive overview of the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of God and the concept of salvation. The philosophy of Christianity is divided into three main sections: the philosophy of the Trinity, the philosophy of the Incarnation, and the philosophy of the Church. The philosophy of the Trinity explores the fundamental principles of God, including the concept of unity and the concept of difference. The philosophy of the Incarnation explores the relationships between God and the world, including the concept of the Messiah and the concept of salvation. The philosophy of the Church explores the relationships between the individual and the external world, including the concept of community and the concept of tradition.

#### Early Romantic writings

Hegel's early Romantic writings are a comprehensive overview of his philosophical ideas, including the concept of the self and the concept of the world. The early Romantic writings are divided into three main sections: the phenomenology of spirit, the psychology of spirit, and the anthropology of spirit. The phenomenology of spirit explores the fundamental principles of self-consciousness, including the concept of the self and the concept of the other. The psychology of spirit explores the relationships between the self and the external world, including the concept of perception and the concept of cognition. The anthropology of spirit explores the relationships between the self and the external world, including the concept of culture and the concept of history.
